"**Brand New Key** " is a [pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music") song written and
sung by [folk](/wiki/Folk_music "Folk music") music singer
[Melanie](/wiki/Melanie_Safka "Melanie Safka"). Initially a track of Melanie's
album _[Gather Me](/wiki/Gather_Me "Gather Me")_ , produced by Melanie's
husband, Peter Schekeryk, it was known also as "The Rollerskate Song" due to
its chorus. It was her greatest success, scoring No. 1 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") singles chart during
December 1971 and January 1972. [Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_charts "Billboard
charts") ranked it as the [No. 9 song of 1972](/wiki/Billboard_Year-
End_Hot_100_singles_of_1972 "Billboard Year-End Hot 100 singles of 1972"). It
also scored No. 1 in [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") and No. 4 on the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"). The song was featured in
the 1997 movie _[Boogie Nights](/wiki/Boogie_Nights "Boogie Nights")_ as well
as the 2010 movie _[Jackass 3D](/wiki/Jackass_3D "Jackass 3D")_ and an episode
of _[Helix](/wiki/Helix_\(TV_series\) "Helix \(TV series\)")_.

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brand_New_Key&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overview")]

The song is sung from the viewpoint of a girl with [roller
skates](/wiki/Roller_skates "Roller skates") trying to attract the attention
of a boy.

In an interview with [Examiner.com](/wiki/Examiner.com "Examiner.com"),
Melanie described what she claimed was the inspiration for the song: "I was
fasting with a 27-day fast on water. I broke the fast and went back to my life
living in [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey") and we were going to a
[flea market](/wiki/Flea_market "Flea market") around six in the morning. On
the way back… and I had just broken the fast, from the flea market, we passed
a [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") and the aroma hit me, and I
had been a vegetarian before the fast. So we pulled into the McDonald's and I
got the whole works... the burger, the shake, and the fries… and no sooner
after I finished that last bite of my burger… that song was in my head. The
aroma brought back memories of roller skating and learning to ride a bike and
the vision of my dad holding the back fender of the tire. And me saying to my
dad... 'You’re holding, you’re holding, you’re holding, right?' Then I’d look
back and he wasn’t holding and I’d fall. So that whole thing came back to me
and came out in this song."[1]

## Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brand_New_Key&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Controversy")]

Many listeners[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] detect sexual [innuendo](/wiki/Innuendo
"Innuendo") in the lyrics, with the key in its lock thought to symbolize
[sexual intercourse](/wiki/Sexual_intercourse "Sexual intercourse"), or in
phrases such as "I go pretty far" and "I've been all around the world".
Another common viewpoint on the song, is that the song is clearly an innocent
reflection upon the typical workings of a child's mind regarding their
possessions (In this case, quad skates and the associated key essential for
tightening/loosening a locking clamp on the skates).

Melanie has acknowledged the possibility of detecting sexual innuendo in the
song, without confirming or denying the intent:

> [The song], "Brand New Key", I wrote in about fifteen minutes one night. I
> thought it was cute; a kind of old thirties tune. I guess a key and a lock
> have always been [Freudian](/wiki/Sigmund_Freud "Sigmund Freud") symbols,
> and pretty obvious ones at that. There was no deep serious expression behind
> the song, but people read things into it. They made up incredible stories as
> to what the lyrics said and what the song meant. In some places, it was even
> banned from the radio.
>
> My idea about songs is that once you write them, you have very little say in
> their life afterward. It's a lot like having a baby. You conceive a song,
> deliver it, and then give it as good a start as you can. After that, it's on
> its own. People will take it any way they want to take it.[2]

## Parodies and other
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brand_New_Key&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Parodies and other versions")]

  * A version of the song entitled "Combine Harvester", with new rustic-themed lyrics by [Irish](/wiki/Irish_people "Irish people") songwriter Brendan O'Shaughnessy (including "I've got a brand new [combine harvester](/wiki/Combine_harvester "Combine harvester") An' I'll give you the key"), was recorded by Irish comedian [Brendan Grace](/wiki/Brendan_Grace "Brendan Grace"), whose version scored No. 1 on the [Irish Charts](/wiki/Irish_Charts "Irish Charts") during 1975. For the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"), [West Country](/wiki/West_Country "West Country") comedy folk act [The Wurzels](/wiki/The_Wurzels "The Wurzels") scored No. 1 for two weeks during June 1976 with a version of this.[14]
  * After the January 1994 attack on [Nancy Kerrigan](/wiki/Nancy_Kerrigan "Nancy Kerrigan"), a parody of "Brand New Key" circulated on radio stations. The parody featured lyrics from [Tonya Harding](/wiki/Tonya_Harding "Tonya Harding")'s point of view, and included the chorus, "I've got a brand new pair of figure skates / You've got a busted knee; / They're gonna lock up my ex-husband and throw away the key."
  * The song was used prominently in the 2005 movie _[Evil Aliens](/wiki/Evil_Aliens "Evil Aliens")_.
  * With lyrics describing Best Film nominee _[Pan's Labyrinth](/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth "Pan's Labyrinth")_, [Minnie Driver](/wiki/Minnie_Driver "Minnie Driver") sang a parody of the song at the 2007 [Spirit Awards](/wiki/Spirit_Awards "Spirit Awards") ("I blew a giant frog to smithereens, I got his golden key").[15]

## References in popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Brand_New_Key&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: References in popular culture")]

Melanie's version is heard in the 1997 music _[Boogie
Nights](/wiki/Boogie_Nights "Boogie Nights")_ as Dirk Diggler ([Mark
Wahlberg](/wiki/Mark_Wahlberg "Mark Wahlberg")) has his "audition" with
Rollergirl ([Heather Graham](/wiki/Heather_Graham "Heather Graham")) in front
of Jack Horner ([Burt Reynolds](/wiki/Burt_Reynolds "Burt Reynolds")).[16] The
song is also played in _[Jackass 3-D](/wiki/Jackass_3-D "Jackass 3-D")_ during
the "Bungee Boogie" stunt skit (in which the cast members use bungee cords,
skateboards and a ramp to slingshot into a kiddie pool). On April 4, 2016,
[Jimmy Fallon](/wiki/Jimmy_Fallon "Jimmy Fallon") lip synced the song during a
"Lip Sync Battle" on _[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy
Fallon](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon "The Tonight Show
Starring Jimmy Fallon")_ , while he competed with actress [Melissa
McCarthy](/wiki/Melissa_McCarthy "Melissa McCarthy").[17]

On the October 17, 2016, episode of singing competition television show _[The
Voice](/wiki/The_Voice_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Voice \(U.S. TV series\)")_ ,
Team [Miley (Cyrus)](/wiki/Miley_Cyrus "Miley Cyrus") contestants Darby Walker
and Karlee Metzger performed the song in a battle round. Despite coaches [Adam
Levine](/wiki/Adam_Levine "Adam Levine"), [Blake Shelton](/wiki/Blake_Shelton
"Blake Shelton"), and [Alicia Keys](/wiki/Alicia_Keys "Alicia Keys") all
preferring Metzger's vocal performance, Cyrus chose to name Walker the winner
of the battle. Shortly after, Metzger was stolen onto Team Blake, saving her
from elimination.

The original version appears in season one of the [FX](/wiki/FX_\(TV_channel\)
"FX \(TV channel\)") show _[The Bridge](/wiki/The_Bridge_\(U.S._TV_series\)
"The Bridge \(U.S. TV series\)")_ , as the character Daniel Frye flushes his
supply of drugs and alcohol.
